entry.title: From Open Source to Help Portal: The Kyma Documentation Journey
entry.content:
Embarking on the journey of migrating Kyma modules documentation from open source to the SAP Help Portal was no small feat. This transition aimed to centralize and enhance the quality of documentation for external Kyma users, ensuring clarity and accessibility.

Planning the Migration and Resetting Mindsets

The journey began with a thorough discovery phase, which included interviews with all SAP BTP, Kyma runtime Product Owners, Lead Architect, Product Manager, and the SAP BTP Foundation Information Architect. We focused on understanding our users and audience as well as grasping the expectations of Kyma developers. This groundwork clarified what external users needed from Kyma documentation and how those needs differed from an open-source audience.

Equally important was a shift in mindset. While open-source documents seemed well-structured, they often blurred the lines between conceptual information and step-by-step procedures. Moving to the Help Portal enabled us to refine, separate, and validate content types so that concepts, tasks, and references were clearly distinguished. This set the tone for how we would write, review, and organize topics throughout the migration.

Piloting Telemetry and Establishing a Repeatable System

Choosing Telemetry as the pilot module was a strategic decision that provided invaluable insights. Working through this module, we developed templates and guidelines that would streamline the documentation process for all subsequent modules. Telemetry underwent numerous review and improvement cycles, which helped us define a repeatable approach: establishing the information architecture, applying consistent standards, iterating on technical accuracy, and polishing language and structure.

The pilot not only produced better content for Telemetry, but also a blueprint for future success. With templates, authoring conventions, and a clear workflow, we were equipped to scale the migration to other Kyma modules without sacrificing quality.

Collaborating for Quality and Consistency

Quality was a shared responsibility. Throughout the migration, we participated in Quality Review Sessions within the BTPX Foundation unit. These sessions provided structured feedback from colleagues outside of Kyma, helping us spot gaps, eliminate ambiguity, and align with SAP Help Portal standards. The cross-team collaboration ensured consistency in style, terminology, and organization across modules, and it accelerated decision-making on tricky or nuanced topics.

Results, Impact, and the Road Ahead

The migration covered 10 Kyma modules over approximately 22 months of non-continuous work, and engaged 5 UA developers. The outcome was about 120 Help Portal topics, each crafted to serve external users with clear conceptual explanations, actionable procedures, and reliable references. Centralizing SAP BTP, Kyma runtime documentation in the Help Portal provides users with a cohesive, comprehensive resource that’s easier to discover, navigate, and trust.

This journey was not just about moving content. It was about elevating the user experience - clarifying what users should understand, guiding them on what they should do, and ensuring the documentation remains a reliable and valuable resource for all. The foundations we built - clear content types, repeatable processes, and cross-team quality practices - position Kyma documentation for ongoing improvement and scalability.

Enjoy reading about  Kyma Modules:

  • Istio Module
  • API Gateway Module
  • SAP BTP Operator Module
  • Cloud Manager Module
  • Application Connector Module
  • Eventing Module
  • Keda Module
  • NATS Module
  • Serverless Module
  • Telemetry Module

Whether you're using the modules or contributing as an author, we welcome your thoughts. Leave your feedback on the SAP Help Portal pages. Your input is key to how we enhance our content.

entry.title: Re: Cancel Billing Document Of Last Month
entry.content:
Dear @Lily16,

In Public Cloud (Manage Billing Documents: F0797):

  • When you press Cancel Billing Document, the system:
    • creates a cancellation billing document and
    • takes the billing date (and posting date) from the original invoice.
  • There is no field in this popup to enter a different date (for example, a date in the current month).

So with pure standard, the only way is:

  1. Temporarily open the old posting period in Manage Posting Periods / Close Periods
  2. Cancel the invoice
  3. Close the period again

This does not meet your requirement to post the cancellation in the current month with one simple action but standard solution provided by SAP in SAP Note, more details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3643140

My proposal how to post the cancellation in the current month (cloud-friendly)

From recent releases, SAP provides:

  • Badi Flexible Billing Document Cancellation- SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/3e9ab63d5fa14080a74adef6024cf521.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/3714184b72b54dad819a7c398a701152.html

 

  • This Badi has been enhanced so you can set a posting date for FI that is different from the billing date for new billing documents and their cancellations.

What you can do:

  1. Activate the configuration step for Flexible Billing Document Cancellation in CBC (Define Custom Routines for Flexible Billing Document Cancellation: 103739)
  2. In the Custom Logic app, create an implementation of Badi
    SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION (Flexible Billing Document Cancellation).
  3. In your custom logic:
    • Check if the period of the original billing date is closed.
    • If it’s closed, you set the Badi changing parameter
    • If the period is open, you leave the posting date unchanged.
  4. End-user experience:
    • User still goes to Manage Billing Documents, selects the invoice, clicks Cancel Billing Document.
    • Your Badi automatically sets the posting date for the cancellation into the current open period.
    • No extra popup or additional app from the user point of view it’s still one simple button.

Summary: You cannot manually enter a date in the Cancel popup, but you can make the system automatically post in the current month via this Badi.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Open Item Management for P&L Account 65008500
entry.content:
Hello @yahaha 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

G/L Account Master Data, Open Item Management, Clear G/L Accounts - Manual Clearing, Balance sheet and Profit and Loss Statement.

  1. Can a P&L account like 65008500 be configured for Open Item Management? --> The simple answer is no.

  2. If it is technically possible, which configuration settings allow the Open Item Management field to appear for this account in the G/L account master data? --> The answer to question 1 anwswer this too.

  3. Are there any SAP standard restrictions or recommended practices that prevent P&L accounts from being cleared in this app? --> Yes there are. See below.

To summarise, the clean-core accounting principle guiding the public cloud does not allow you to enable a P&L account such as 65008500 (Outsourced Services) for Open Item Management (OIM). The system only permits OIM for balance-sheet accounts that require reconciliation (e.g., GR/IR, bank clearing and tax clearing). P&L accounts are always cleared automatically at period-end and the system prevents OIM activation to avoid conflicts with the year-end closing logic. Therefore, Open Item Management will not appear in the master data of any P&L account and no SSCUI in public cloud can make it visible. As a result, the P&L accounts will not appear in the Clear G/L Accounts app.

If your business requires reconciliation of outsourced-service costs, I recommend adhering to a clean-core approach by using Cost objects, supplier subledger clearing and custom analytical queries for reporting.

Let me know if you have further questions. 

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Clarification on OB57 User Assignment and Impact of D...
entry.content:
Scenario 1: All users deleted from OB57 → everyone uses blank tolerance group

Suppose in OBA4 (blank tolerance group) you set:

  • Maximum document amount = 100,000
  • Payment difference allowed = 50
  • Cash discount allowed = 2%

Example:

  • User A (junior accountant) tries to post a vendor invoice of 80,000 → Allowed (within 100,000).
  • User B (manager) tries to post a vendor invoice of 120,000 → Error (exceeds 100,000).
  • Any user tries to clear a payment difference of 60 →  Error (exceeds 50).

Impact: Everyone has the same limits, regardless of role or responsibility.

 

Scenario 2: Users assigned to OB57 tolerance groups 

Suppose you define two tolerance groups in OBA4:

Then in OB57:

  • Assign User A to TG1
  • Assign User B to TG2

Example:

  • User A (junior) tries to post invoice of 80,000 →  Error (limit is 50,000).
  • User B (Manager) tries to post invoice of 120,000 →  Allowed (limit is 200,000).
  • User A tries to clear payment difference of 30 →  Error (limit is 20).
  • User B tries to clear payment difference of 90 →  Allowed (limit is 100).

Impact: You can differentiate authorization levels by role, ensuring tighter internal control.

entry.content:
Hello Team,

1. We are not able to delete Storage bin in our warehouse 0028. Storage type- LG15, Storage bin-   A-17-3-0

If the error occurs in one of your own ABAP programs or an SAP program
that you have modified, try to correct the error yourself.
If the error occurs in a non-modfied SAP program, you might be able to
find a solution in the SAP Notes system. If you have access to the SAP
Notes system, check there first using the following keywords:

"ASSERTION_FAILED"
"/LIME/SAPLCORE" bzw. /LIME/LCORENOI
"SELECT_NODE"
If you cannot solve the problem yourself, please send the following
information to SAP:

1. The description of the problem (short dump)
To do this, choose  System -> List -> Save -> Local File (unconverted)
on the screen you are in now.

2. The relevant system log
To do this, call the system log in transaction SM21. Restrict the time
interval to ten minutes before the short dump and five minutes after
it. In the display, choose System -> Lis

entry.title: Project Foxhound - on the Scent of Client-Side Web Vulnerabilities
entry.content:
In this article, we show how the open-source Project Foxhound has evolved from its academic roots to become the best tool for discovering client-side security vulnerabilities. 

The most recent development on this journey is that Foxhound was selected to appear as part of Black Hat Arsenal 2025 in London in December! If you are attending the conference, be sure to check out our demo, where we are hoping to reveal some exciting new features and integrations! 

 

Background

The world-wide-web is one of the most pervasive innovations of the modern age, underpinning communications, banking, education and business. However, programming flaws or misconfigurations can cause security vulnerabilities, exposing the systems and their data to malicious attackers. According to a recent report from IBM, the average cost of a Cybersecurity data breach is $4.4M. 

In recent years, web applications have seen a paradigm shift from on-premise, monolithic server applications, to heterogeneous collections of cloud-based microservices. As such, much of the application logic has shifted from the server to the client, with program logic running as JavaScript code in a user's browser. This shift has brought with it new classes of client-side (or DOM-based) web vulnerabilities, for example: 

  • Client-Side Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) 
  • Client-Side Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) 
  • Request Hijacking 
  • Markup Injection 

Most state-of-the-art tools, however, are still focused on detection of their server-side counterparts (such as reflected XSS). Hunting for client-side issues, remains a manual effort, requiring time-intensive and costly penetration tests. 

                          Figure 1: JavaScript vulnerable to client-side XSS

 

Project Foxhound

This is where project Foxhound comes in – providing a state-of-the-art framework for the detection of client-side web application vulnerabilities. It has seen a wide range of proven use-cases, from academic studies to industrial-scale dynamic testing and even education.

Features

Foxhound is a modified web browser based on Firefox with the following enhancements: 

  • An instrumented JavaScript engine and content model to track insecure data-flows using dynamic taint-tracking.  
  • Taint tracking makes it possible to automatically detect client-side vulnerabilities by tainting certain attacker-controlled strings, e.g., location.hash, and notifying the user when tainted data reaches a sensitive sink, e.g., eval() or .innerHTML. 
  • Foxhound also tracks a history of operations performed on the string a runtime, allowing automatic detection of potential input sanitization which essentially reduces false positives. 
  • Integration with popular browser automation frameworks, such as Selenium and Playwright.  

History 

The technology for Foxhound was conceived at SAP Security Research back in 2013, where it was successfully used to discover that at least 10% of web applications are vulnerable to cross-site scripting. This paper spawned multiple follow-ups, with many research groups implementing their own instrumented browsers, which is not a trivial task! 

We saw the need in the community for an open-source, up-to-date tool for teams to use as a platform for their own research. This gap was the main inspiration to open-source our implementation, which was released in 2022 – and Foxhound was born!  

Since then, the Foxhound community has grown from the initial founders at SAP and Braunschweig and is currently in use by groups at CISPA (Germany), Waterloo (Canada), and Venice (Italy). With the support of the SAP Open Source team, the project has evolved and matured, appearing in podcasts, at conferences, and even has a new logo! 

Foxhound has also proven its worth in industry, with SAP using it to dynamically test UI5 applications since 2023 as part of the award-winning FioriDAST tool. 

Why Foxhound?! 

Foxhound offers several advantages over existing tools and techniques to outperform the competition. Firstly, as Foxhound uses dynamic testing, it benefits from lower false positives and higher accuracy compared to static analysis techniques. Secondly, Foxhound is non-invasive and does not require actively probing an application with potentially harmful and inaccurate payloads. 

In fact, a recent independent academic study found that Foxhound was the best tool for dynamic JavaScript analysis. To quote the paper: "the only effective solution given the current state of the art is Project Foxhound." 

 Figure 2: Foxhound hard at work detecting a cross-site scripting vulnerability at https://domgo.at  

 

Find out More 

The next opportunity to experience Foxhound live and meet the team in person will be at Black Hat Europe, where Foxhound has been selected to appear as part of the Arsenal program. So be sure to pass by our booth to check out the latest features! 

If you can’t make it to Black Hat, but are still interested in the project, check out the following links: 

  • The best place to find out more is on our GitHub repository where we also manage development via issues and pull requests and actions. 
  • Binaries for selected platforms are provided by the University of Braunschweig on a dedicated server. 
  • More resources include academic papers, talks at IEEE S&P 2025 and the German OWASP day, and even a Podcast! 

Authors of this Article

  • Thomas Barber, Product Security Expert, SAP BTP
  • Ulrike Fempel, SAP Open Source Program Office

entry.title: ALV TREE: Select ALL - Deselect ALL
entry.content:
Hello,

I’ve created two new buttons in my ALV TREE to check and uncheck rows, since I don’t see a standard functionality for this. Please correct me if I’m wrong.

Each node was created using the ADD_NODE method with the following layout:

ls_item_layout-fieldname = go_alv_tree->c_hierarchy_column_name.
ls_item_layout-class     = cl_gui_column_tree=>item_class_checkbox.
ls_item_layout-editable  = abap_true.
ls_item_layout-style     = cl_gui_column_tree=>style_emphasized_c. 
APPEND ls_item_layout TO lt_item_layout.

 I’ve registered the event cl_gui_column_tree=>eventid_checkbox_change so that changes are reflected in the backend and I can correctly retrieve the checked nodes using the GET_CHECKED_ITEMS method.

However, there is no public method in the CL_GUI_ALV_TREE class to programmatically check or uncheck nodes. There is the protected method UPDATE_CHECKED_ITEMS, which modifies the also-protected attribute MT_CHECKED_ITEMS.

So I created a subclass to call this method, and I can see that the nodes are being removed from MT_CHECKED_ITEMS correctly.

The problem is that in the frontend they still appear checked. I cannot seem to get them to visually uncheck, even though the table no longer contains them.

 

I’ve tried calling the following after UPDATE_CHECKED_ITEMS, but it doesn’t work:

CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->frontend_update.
cl_gui_cfw=>flush( ).

I also tried redefining UPDATE_CHECKED_ITEMS and calling the SUPER method, which seems to trigger the CHECKBOX_CHANGE event, but still no luck — the nodes continue to appear checked on screen.

Would anyone know how to solve this?

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Part 2 - Building the MCP Server and client for SAP Commerce in Local
entry.content:
In the last two blogs, we explored the why and what of MCP — understanding how it bridges intelligent agents with enterprise APIs, and how we can design metadata-driven tools to make this communication seamless.

Now, we’re stepping into the how.
In this hands-on article, we’ll build our own MCP Server and Client, wire them up to SAP Commerce, and actually see how the ecosystem communicates end-to-end. This phase of the learning journey is where theory meets practice. You’ll see how each moving part — the MCP server, client, and SAP Commerce APIs — fit together to make machines understand your business

🧩 Prerequisites

Before we start, make sure your setup is ready: This is a real integration, so we need all the moving parts: ✅SAP Commerce (local instance running OCC APIs) Running on

https://localhost:9002/occ/v2/swagger-ui/index.html#/Products/getProducts

Node.js 20+

node -v

NPM

npm -v

OLLAMA

Ollama (LLM runtime)
Install on macOS:
brew install ollama
ollama start
ollama pull llama3

 Creating the MCP Tools Manifest (mcp_tools.yaml)

tools:
  - name: findProductsUnderPrice
    description: "Find top products under a given max price."
    endpoint: "https://localhost:9002/occ/v2/electronics/products/search"
    method: "GET"
    input_schema:
      type: object
      properties:
        query:
          type: string
        maxPrice:
          type: integer
        pageSize:
          type: integer
      required:
        - query
    output_schema:
      type: object

  - name: addToCart
    description: "Add a product SKU to an existing cart (dev only - requires cartId)."
    endpoint: "https://localhost:9002/occ/v2/users/current/carts/{cartId}/entries"
    method: "POST"
    input_schema:
      type: object
      properties:
        cartId:
          type: string
        sku:
          type: string
        qty:
          type: integer
      required:
        - cartId
        - sku
    output_schema:
      type: object

Our MCP Server repo structure

commerce-mcp/
  ├── server/
  ├── client/
  ├── mcp_tools.yaml

Create the folder

mkdir commerce-mcp 
cd commerce-mcp 
npm init -y 
npm install

MCP Server Setup (Server.js)

// server/server.js
import express from "express";
import bodyParser from "body-parser";
import cors from "cors";
import fs from "fs";
import axios from "axios";
import yamlLib from "js-yaml";
import path from "path";

const app = express();

// Standard middleware
app.use(bodyParser.json());
app.use(cors());

// DEV: simple request logger - keep for debugging, remove for prod
app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log(`[MCP-REQ] ${new Date().toISOString()} ${req.method} ${req.url}`);
  // log body chunks if present (best-effort)
  req.on("data", (chunk) => {
    try {
      const s = chunk.toString();
      if (s && s.trim().length) console.log("[MCP-REQ-BODY]", s);
    } catch (e) {}
  });
  next();
});

// Load MCP tools YAML (relative to project root)
const yamlPath = path.resolve(process.cwd(), "../mcp_tools.yaml");
let tools = [];
try {
  const yaml = fs.readFileSync(yamlPath, "utf8");
  tools = yamlLib.load(yaml).tools || [];
  console.log(`[MCP] Loaded ${tools.length} tools from ${yamlPath}`);
} catch (err) {
  console.warn("[MCP] Warning: failed to load mcp_tools.yaml:", err.message);
  // continue with empty tools - useful for development
}

// Simple endpoint to view registered tools
app.get("/tools", (req, res) => {
  res.json({ tools: tools.map(t => ({ name: t.name, description: t.description })) });
});

// Main execute handler
app.post("/execute", async (req, res) => {
  const { toolName, input } = req.body || {};
  console.log(`[MCP] /execute called tool=${toolName} input=${JSON.stringify(input)}`);

  const tool = tools.find(t => t.name === toolName);
  if (!tool) {
    console.log("[MCP] Tool not found:", toolName);
    return res.status(404).json({ error: "Tool not found" });
  }

  try {
    // Build query params (use 'query' commonly used by OCC)
    const params = new URLSearchParams({
      query: input?.query || "",
      pageSize: input?.pageSize || 20,
      fields: input?.fields || "FULL"
    });

    const url = tool.endpoint + "?" + params.toString();
    console.log(`[MCP] Calling Commerce URL: ${url}`);

    const resp = await axios.get(url, {
      headers: process.env.COMMERCE_TOKEN ? { Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.COMMERCE_TOKEN}` } : {},
      validateStatus: null // allow non-2xx so we can inspect body
    });

    console.log(`[MCP] Commerce responded status=${resp.status}`);

    if (resp.status >= 400) {
      // Forward upstream body for debugging
      return res.status(502).json({
        error: "Commerce API returned error",
        status: resp.status,
        data: resp.data
      });
    }

    const data = resp.data || {};
    const productList = Array.isArray(data.products) ? data.products : [];
    const maxPrice = Number(input?.maxPrice ?? Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER);

    const results = productList.filter(p => {
      const price = Number(p?.price?.value ?? Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER);
      return price <= maxPrice;
    });

    return res.json({
      tool: toolName,
      input,
      resultCount: results.length,
      results
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("[MCP] execute exception:", err && (err.stack || err.message || err));
    const upstream = err?.response ? { status: err.response.status, data: err.response.data } : null;
    return res.status(500).json({ error: err.message, upstream, stack: err.stack });
  }
});

// Start server
const PORT = process.env.PORT || 4000;
app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log(`🧩 MCP Server running at http://localhost:${PORT}`);
});

MCP Client Folder Initialization

cd ../client 
npm init -y 
npm install axios inquirer

MCP Client (client\client.js)

import axios from "axios";
import inquirer from "inquirer";
import { spawnSync } from "child_process";

/** runOllama(prompt) -> string (stdout) **/
function runOllama(prompt, model = "llama3", timeoutMs = 30000) {
  const child = spawnSync("ollama", ["run", model], {
    input: prompt,
    encoding: "utf8",
    maxBuffer: 50 * 1024 * 1024,
    timeout: timeoutMs
  });

  if (child.error) throw child.error;
  if (child.status !== 0) {
    throw new Error(`Ollama failed (status=${child.status}): ${child.stderr || child.stdout}`);
  }
  return child.stdout;
}

/** Try to safely extract JSON from an LLM response (handles extraneous text) **/
function extractJson(text) {
  text = (text || "").trim();
  try { return JSON.parse(text); } catch (e) {}
  const match = text.match(/\{[\s\S]*\}/);
  if (match) {
    try { return JSON.parse(match[0]); } catch (e) {}
  }
  throw new Error("Failed to parse JSON from LLM output. Raw:\n" + text.slice(0, 2000));
}

function normalizeProducts(serverResp) {
  if (!serverResp) return [];
  if (Array.isArray(serverResp)) return serverResp;
  if (Array.isArray(serverResp.results)) return serverResp.results;
  if (Array.isArray(serverResp.products)) return serverResp.products;
  if (serverResp.result && Array.isArray(serverResp.result.products)) return serverResp.result.products;
  return [];
}

async function main() {
  console.log("🧠 MCP Client ready (fully automated add-to-cart mode).\n");

  const { query, maxPrice, pageSize } = await inquirer.prompt([
    { name: "query", message: "Search for:", default: "running shoes" },
    { name: "maxPrice", message: "Max price?", default: "10000" },
    { name: "pageSize", message: "pageSize?", default: "10" }
  ]);

  console.log("🔍 Searching via MCP Server...");

  let resp;
  try {
    resp = await axios.post("http://localhost:4000/execute", {
      toolName: "findProductsUnderPrice",
      input: { query, maxPrice: Number(maxPrice), pageSize: Number(pageSize) }
    }, { timeout: 20000 });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Error calling MCP Server:", err.response?.data || err.message);
    return;
  }

  const products = normalizeProducts(resp.data) || [];

  if (products.length === 0) {
    console.log("No products returned from Commerce for that query.");
    return;
  }

  // Display products brief
  console.log(`\n🛒 Received ${products.length} products from Commerce (showing up to ${pageSize}):\n`);
  products.slice(0, Number(pageSize)).forEach((p, idx) => {
    const code = p.code || p.id || p.productCode || p.sku || "unknown-sku";
    const name = p.name || p.title || p.productName || "Unnamed product";
    const price = (p.price && (p.price.value ?? p.price)) ?? (p.priceValue ?? "N/A");
    console.log(`[${idx}] ${name} — sku: ${code} — price: ${price}`);
  });

  // Ask Ollama to pick the best product (return JSON with bestIndex and reason)
  console.log("\n🤖 Asking Ollama to pick the best product for the user's query (automated)...\n");

  const prompt = `You are a shopping assistant. Given the list of products below (JSON array), pick the single best product
for the user's intent "Find ${query} under ${maxPrice}". Consider reviews, price, value-for-money, and overall suitability for running.
Return valid JSON ONLY, in this exact shape:

{
  "bestIndex": <integer index into the provided array>,
  "reason": "<one-sentence reason>"
}

Products:
${JSON.stringify(products.slice(0, Number(pageSize)), null, 2)}

Make sure bestIndex is a valid zero-based index referencing the array above.`;

  let llmOut;
  try {
    llmOut = runOllama(prompt);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Ollama error:", err.message);
    return;
  }

  let choiceObj;
  try {
    choiceObj = extractJson(llmOut);
  } catch (e) {
    console.error(e.message);
    console.log("\nRaw LLM output (for debugging):\n", llmOut);
    return;
  }

  const bestIndex = Number(choiceObj.bestIndex);
  const reason = String(choiceObj.reason || "").trim();

  if (!Number.isFinite(bestIndex) || bestIndex < 0 || bestIndex >= Math.min(products.length, Number(pageSize))) {
    console.error(`Invalid bestIndex returned by Ollama: ${choiceObj.bestIndex}`);
    console.log("Raw LLM output:\n", llmOut);
    return;
  }

  const bestProduct = products[bestIndex];
  const bestSku = bestProduct.code || bestProduct.id || bestProduct.productCode || bestProduct.sku;
  const bestName = bestProduct.name || bestProduct.title || bestProduct.productName || "Unnamed product";
  const bestPrice = (bestProduct.price && (bestProduct.price.value ?? bestProduct.price)) ?? (bestProduct.priceValue ?? "N/A");

  console.log("\n🔎 Ollama's pick:");
  console.log(`Index: ${bestIndex}`);
  console.log(`Product: ${bestName}`);
  console.log(`SKU: ${bestSku}`);
  console.log(`Price: ${bestPrice}`);
  console.log(`Reason: ${reason}`);

  // AUTOMATIC: proceed to add to cart without asking user
  const defaultQty = 1;
  const cartIdentifier = "new"; // let server create a cart if supported

  const inputPayload = {
    cartId: cartIdentifier === "new" ? null : cartIdentifier,
    sku: bestSku,
    qty: Number(defaultQty)
  };

  try {
    console.log(`\n🛠️ Automatically adding SKU ${bestSku} (qty ${defaultQty}) to cart...`);
    const addResp = await axios.post("http://localhost:4000/execute", {
      toolName: "addToCart",
      input: inputPayload
    }, { timeout: 20000 });

    const addData = addResp.data;
    console.log("\n✅ Add to cart response:");
    console.log(JSON.stringify(addData, null, 2));

    const returnedCartId = addData.cartId || addData.code || addData.cartIdPK || null;
    console.log(`\nCart ID: ${returnedCartId || "(not returned by server)"} — SKU added: ${bestSku} — qty: ${defaultQty}`);

  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Failed to add to cart:", err.response?.data || err.message);
    return;
  }

  console.log("\nDone (automated).");
}

main();

Start the MCP Server:

Goto the server folder and run
export NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED=0
node server.js

 Test MCP Server

Check if the server is aware about the tools that we exposed. For that try this
curl -sS http://localhost:4000/tools | jq .
{
  "tools": [
    {
      "name": "findProductsUnderPrice",
      "description": "Find top products under a given max price."
    },
    {
      "name": "addToCart",
      "description": "Add a product SKU to an existing cart (dev only - requires cartId)."
    }
  ]
}

Testing the MCP Client

i575688@H2L2R74525 client % node client.js
🧠 MCP Client ready.

✔ Search for: camera
✔ Max price? 10000
✔ pageSize? 10
🔍 Searching via MCP Server...

🛒 Received 10 products from Commerce (showing up to 10):

[0] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> — sku: CONF_CAMERA_SL — price: 1000
[1] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> Tripod — sku: 932577 — price: 24.47
[2] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> Professional Black — sku: CONF_CAMERA_SL-PROF-BLACK — price: 3300
[3] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> Professional Metallic — sku: CONF_CAMERA_SL-PROF-METALLIC — price: 3440
[4] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> Standard Black — sku: CONF_CAMERA_SL-STD-BLACK — price: 1100
[5] Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> Standard Metallic — sku: CONF_CAMERA_SL-STD-METALLIC — price: 1240
[6] DIGITAL <em class="search-results-highlight">CAMERA</em> EASYSHARE C875 — sku: 489702 — price: 227.24
[7] Photosmart E317 Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> — sku: 300938 — price: 114.12
[8] <em class="search-results-highlight">CAMERA</em> TAPE DIGITAL8 90MIN 2PK — sku: 149243 — price: 19.69
[9] EASYSHARE Z730 Zoom Digital <em class="search-results-highlight">Camera</em> — sku: 325414 — price: 147.04

🤖 Asking Ollama to pick the best product for the user's query...

Failed to parse JSON from LLM output. Raw:
I can help you with that!

After reviewing the products in the JSON array, I found the product with the highest price.

Here's the result:

The best camera is the "EASYSHARE Z730 Zoom Digital Camera" (index 3) with a price of $147.04.

Raw LLM output (for debugging):
 I can help you with that!

After reviewing the products in the JSON array, I found the product with the highest price.

Here's the result:

The best camera is the "EASYSHARE Z730 Zoom Digital Camera" (index 3) with a price of $147.04.

 

Errors We Hit (And How We Fixed Them)

Every real build has bumps.
Here is a compact table of all issues we hit and exactly how we fixed them:

Error

Cause

Fix

MODULE_TYPELESS_PACKAGE_JSON

ES modules without "type":"module"

Add "type":"module"

ERR_MODULE_NOT_FOUND js-yaml

missing dependency

npm install js-yaml

MCP Server returns only “server running”

missing error logs

Added upstream error logging

unable to verify the first certificate

Commerce SSL self-signed cert

Added HTTPS agent rejectUnauthorized:false

HTTP 500 without logs

upstream Commerce failure

Bubble up full error JSON

Raw XML from Commerce

missing Accept: application/json

Added header + XML→JSON fallback

jq parse error

Commerce returned HTML/XML error

Logged raw body, corrected Commerce request

Shell syntax errors from Ollama

using execSync (shell pipe)

Switched to spawnSync with stdin

Ollama returns raw XML

LLM not in loop

Built agent.js to orchestrate

LLM doesn’t know tools

tools never provided

Embedded manifest in system prompt

This section alone will save future developers 10+ hours.

Conclusion: We Made MCP Real

You now have:

✔ A local MCP Server
✔ A working manifest
✔ A Node.js agent that mimics MCP Client behavior
✔ SAP Commerce connected to LLM via MCP
✔ A fully functional shopping assistant

If you’ve been looking for a hands-on reference that goes beyond diagrams, you’ve just built one.

This is part of the SAP Blog series 

Demystifying MCP: A Practical Journey to AI-Powered Commerce with SAP

Part 1 – Understanding MCP: The Brain Behind Collaborative AI

entry.title: Re: In sap public cloud check stock based on WBS
entry.content:
Dear @R971,

Yes in Public Cloud there is a way to see stock by WBS element you use the Fiori app: Stock Multiple Materials: F1595 or Stock Single Material: F1076

There isn’t a separate app called Stock by WBS but above apps has a WBS Element filter and shows project stock (Q), so it’s exactly what you need.

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1595')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1076')/S35

How to check stock by WBS element:

  1. Open the app
    • In the Fiori Launchpad search for Stock Multiple Materials
    • Typically available in roles that you will find it in the links above
  2. Add WBS Element to the filter bar
    • In the app, click Adapt Filters.
    • Add WBS Element and optionally Special Stock
    • Confirm

 

 

  1. Filter specifically for project stock
    • Set:
      • Plant
      • Special Stock = Q (Project stock)
      • WBS Element the WBS you want to analyze
    • Click Go
  2. Read the result
    • You’ll see all materials and quantities held under that WBS element as project stock
    • You can export to Excel or save your filter as a variant for example Project stock by WBS

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/31be7e548af58e4ce10000000a4450e5.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/d137e156ff2cf777e10000000a4450e5.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Accounting position text
entry.content:
Hello @ShiZhekui 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Manage Journal Entries, Subsequent Debits / Subsequent Credits, Item Texts, Item-Based Accounting, Relevant Scope Items.

To summarise, the public cloud due to its clean-core approach, does not allow you to change the Item Text of accounting lines that originates from logistics process such as GR, Invoice receipt, subsequent debit and stock posting. You can only edit FI-origin lines. The systems put up these restrictions to ensure document integrity between MM and FI, ensuring your audit integrity and prevents inconsistencies by not allowing you to modify it.

Open your Manage Journal Entries app

Select the logistics-derived line item. If the Item field remains locked, then it confirms the logic and this is what you have on your screen too.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Accessing BTP User Security Using APIs of the SAP Authorization and Trust Management Service
entry.content:
Introduction

Identity and Access Management lies at the core of an organization's Digital infrastructure. In SAP's BTP ecosystem, identities are provisioned in SAP Identity Services and roles are granted in BTP. 

This blog aims to capture my learnings during my investigations to fetch Users and their assigned roles in BTP using APIs, which then can be later read to an Organization's IAM system for User lifecycle management.

I am targeting this API call to the BTP subaccount rather than the SAP IAS tenant as we were looking to not only interested in fetching the users in BTP but the assigned BTP roles as well.

Pre-requisite

You have BTP CLI installed. If not, you can download and install following the instructions from Download and Start Using the btp CLI Client | SAP Help Portal

Create a credential for API access

Create a credential to call he REST APIs of the SAP Authorization and Trust Management service. Credentials can be created on global account, subaccount, or directory level.

Log in to your BTP global account. Your first login takes you into a global account, and all your commands are executed on a global account level. In my case, I would like my commands to be executed on a specific subaccount, so do so by using the "btp target" command.

btp cli login

 

 

 

 

btp targetOnce you are in the desired BTP target, create the api-credential using command btp create security/api-credential --name my-credential

Store the these details in a secure location or password manager, as you will not be able to retrieve the client ID & secret later.

Call the API

We will test the API using Postman

We can use the different endpoints of the SAP Authorization and Trust Management service APIs to manage users roles and other authorization configurations

Actually, we need two separate URLs. First, you need the token URL to fetch an access token. Next, you can use the API URL to call an API.

To call an API of the SAP Authorization and Trust Management service, you need an access token. See the following example how to retrieve an access token and how to call an endpoint with GET request

Configure postman to request a token from the OAuth authorization server

Create a new collection from template "REST API basics". In the POST call, add the Token URL from the create API credential step. Add the below parameter to the post call.

KeyValue
grant_typeclient_credentials

In the Authorization tab, select Auth Type "Basic Auth". In the Username & Password fields, enter the client ID & secret.\

Once you click send, the authorization server returns a token along with other related information

We can now use the value of this access_token property to make calls to the various API endpoints

With a GET request, we can now call the API end point to request the list of users and their details. With the Auth type selected to "Bearer Token" and paste the Token we received from the above step.

You can refer to Try Out | User Management (System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM)) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub for other API endpoints for User Management.

Conclusion

To summarize, this blog's main goal was to document my learnings for a niche request where we would need to fetch a BTP subaccount User list and their assigned roles in BTP.  I have used postman for testing the API calls for the purpose of this demonstration, but for a production scenario the 3rd party IAM system can connect to the BTP subaccount security in the same way.  As I mentioned in the Introduction, I am targeting this API call to the BTP subaccount rather than the SAP IAS tenant as we were looking to not only interested in fetching the users in BTP but the assigned BTP roles as well. Hence, Ideally for user provision and management we can use another set of API calls targeting the SAP IAS Tenant

Based on interest, I may create another blog with steps for API calls to SAP IAS tenant for User Provisioning. Tenant management etc.

entry.title: Re: GRPO Remains Open Even Though Item Quantities, Freigh...
entry.content:
Hi,

When an AP invoice is created using Copy from --> GRPO, it is possible to copy the GRPO partially, and add lines or quantities that are not in the GRPO. When you play around with this, it is possible to break the link between AP invoice line and GRPO line.

Please check the GRPO for any lines that remain open. A quick check can be performed by using the 'Copy to' function from the GRPO. If any lines / quantities remain open, they will be copied to the target document.

Regards,

Johan

entry.title: Validating Local vs Application Server File Paths in ABAP
entry.content:
Hi Everyone – My Motivation for Writing This

I recently worked on a requirement where users were uploading and processing files in an ABAP program. During testing, I noticed that many errors occurred simply because the file path was either incorrect or pointing to the wrong location (local system vs SAP application server).
Since this is a common challenge—especially in data migration and background processing—I decided to document a clean and reusable approach.
I prepared this post with the help of a generative AI tool, but all code, explanations, and examples reflect my own experience on an SAP S/4HANA system.

Why Validating File Paths Matters

Before reading the file, ABAP must know where it is located:

  • File Uploads: Detect if the user is picking a file from their PC.

  • File Export: Decide whether to save on SAP server or local desktop.

  • Batch/Background Jobs: Only application-server paths are allowed.

  • Data Migration: Large files usually reside on the SAP server.

  • File Processing: Avoid runtime errors caused by invalid paths.

Approach

In ABAP, local (presentation server) files are handled through CL_GUI_FRONTEND_SERVICES, while server files use OPEN DATASET.
So the idea is:

  1. Check if the path exists on the local system.

  2. If not, try accessing it as an application server path.

  3. If both fail → invalid path.

Example Program Code :

REPORT zsap_val_path.

DATA: lv_file_exist TYPE abap_bool VALUE abap_false,
      lv_dir_exist  TYPE abap_bool VALUE abap_false,
      file_type     TYPE char10,
      file_path     TYPE string.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b2 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-002.
PARAMETERS: p_fname TYPE string LOWER CASE.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b2.

"-------------------------------------------------------
" F4 Help – Let user browse directories on local machine
"-------------------------------------------------------
AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_fname.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_browse
    CHANGING
      selected_folder = p_fname
    EXCEPTIONS
      cntl_error           = 1
      error_no_gui         = 2
      not_supported_by_gui = 3
      OTHERS               = 4.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'File path not selected' TYPE 'E' DISPLAY LIKE 'W'.
  ENDIF.


"-------------------------------------------------------
" Validate Path
"-------------------------------------------------------
file_path = p_fname.

TRY.
    "Check if it's a LOCAL file
    cl_gui_frontend_services=>file_exist(
      EXPORTING file   = file_path
      RECEIVING result = lv_file_exist ).

    "If not a file, check if it's a LOCAL directory
    IF lv_file_exist = abap_false.
      cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_exist(
        EXPORTING directory = file_path
        RECEIVING result    = lv_dir_exist ).
    ENDIF.

  CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_root).
    lv_file_exist = abap_false.
    lv_dir_exist  = abap_false.
ENDTRY.


"-------------------------------------------------------
" Determine: Local (LOC) or Application Server (APP)
"-------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_file_exist = abap_true OR lv_dir_exist = abap_true.
  file_type = 'LOC'.
ELSE.
  "Try Application Server
  OPEN DATASET file_path FOR INPUT IN BINARY MODE.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    CLOSE DATASET file_path.
    file_type = 'APP'.
  ELSE.
    MESSAGE 'Invalid path. Enter a valid LOCAL or Application Server path.'
      TYPE 'E'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.
ENDIF.


"-------------------------------------------------------
" Output
"-------------------------------------------------------
CASE file_type.
  WHEN 'APP'.
    WRITE: 'APPLICATION SERVER PATH'.
  WHEN 'LOC'.
    WRITE: 'LOCAL FILE PATH (PRESENTATION SERVER)'.
  WHEN OTHERS.
    WRITE: 'UNKNOWN FILE TYPE'.
ENDCASE.

From my experience, users often assume a path will behave the same in dialog and background modes—but that’s not true.
Always remember:
 Local files work only in GUI mode
 Background jobs can only access application-server paths

This validation step saves a lot of debugging time later.
Thank You !!

ABAP Development

entry.title: Create a CAP Application with SAP HANA Cloud from Scratch and Deploy to Cloud Foundry in SAP BTP
entry.content:
Create a CAP Application with SAP HANA Cloud from Scratch and Deploy to Cloud Foundry

This guide walks you through the complete lifecycle of building a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application, connecting it to SAP HANA Cloud, and deploying it to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry.

 

1.Create SAP BTP Trial Account

You need a trial account to access Cloud Foundry, SAP HANA Cloud, and all BAS development tools.

 

2. Subscribe to SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)

If not subscribed:

  1. Go to SAP BTP Cockpit → Instances and Subscriptions
  2. Subscribe to Business Application Studio

 

3. Create CAP Project Skeleton (Using Template Wizard)

Open BAS and press:

Ctrl + Shift + P → Template Wizard

 

Then follow these steps:

3.1 Select Template

  • Select: CAP Project Generator
  • Click Next

 

3.2 Provide Project Details

  • Project Name → Any name of your choice
  • Choose Database → SQLite (default)
  • Choose Deployment Target → Cloud Foundry

Note:
Do not select SAP HANA Cloud here.
We first deploy the application with SQLite, then add HANA later from terminal.

 

3.3 Choose Runtime Capabilities

Select these productive services:

  • XSUAA
  • SAP BTP Connectivity Service
  • SAP BTP Destination Service
  • SAP BTP Application Router

Click Finish.

This creates the complete folder structure including:

  • /db
  • /srv
  • /app
  • mta.yaml
  • Security and deployment artifacts

 

 

4. Modify MTA Configuration

Cloud Foundry sometimes fails when resource names contain dynamic interpolation (org/space).

Removing them ensures deployment simplicity.

Open mta.yaml and remove:

-${org}-${space}

from all resource names.

 

5. Create a Sample CAP Model

5.1 Define Database Schema

Open /db/schema.cds:

 

5.2 Create Service Definition

Open /srv/service.cds:

Now, you have a simple end-to-end data + service model to validate local and cloud deployment.

 

6. Test the CAP Application Locally

 

cds w

Now, CAP runs using SQLite, allowing quick testing without any external services.

 

 

 7. Deploy the CAP Application (SQLite Mode)

  1. Right-click mta.yaml → Build MTA Project
    • Or use: 
mbt build

        2. Login to Cloud Foundry
               Ctrl + Shift + P → CF Login

         3. Deploy the generated .mtar

    • Right-click .mtar → Deploy MTA Archive
    • Or use:
    • cf deploy yourfile.mtar

Your CAP app runs in Cloud Foundry with SQLite.

 

Next, we will connect it to real SAP HANA Cloud

 

8. Create SAP HANA Cloud Instance

Go to:

SAP BTP Cockpit → Instances & Subscriptions → Create

Choose:

  • Service: SAP HANA Cloud
  • Plan: hana
  • Environment: Cloud Foundry
  • Instance Name: hanaDB

Set the DB administrator password → required for Data Explorer.

 

And press on Create instance.

It will take estimated 10-15min

It creates the actual HANA database where CAP HDI containers will be deployed.

 

9. Subscribe to SAP HANA Cloud Tools

Without this subscription, you cannot access the DB instance UI.

Go to:
Instances & Subscriptions → Subscribe → SAP HANA Cloud Tools

Assign Roles

Under Users, assign all required HANA Cloud roles.

Sign out → Sign in again.

 

10. Open SAP HANA Data Explorer

Click the HANA instance → Open SAP HANA Database Explorer

 

First login:

  • Username: DBADMIN (or the username shown under "Administrator")
  • Password: the one you entered during instance creation

If you forgot your DB username

Open:
SAP HANA Cloud Administration → Overview
Your administrator username will be displayed there.

 

Now, You have direct access to schemas, HDI containers, and database objects.

 

11. Open HDI Container Section in SAP HANA Database Explorer

Inside SAP HANA Database Explorer:

  1. Click the “+” icon
  2. Choose Cloud Foundry
  3. Log in to your CF environment

 

  1. From the list → choose Instance Type: HDI Container

At this stage, your CAP HDI container will NOT appear yet, because we have not created it.

 

12. Add HANA Support to CAP Application

Run the following commands in BAS terminal:

cds add hana
npm i

What these commands do

  • cds add hana
    • Generates HANA-specific configuration
    • Creates HDI deployment artifacts
    • Prepares the project to run on SAP HANA instead of SQLite
  • npm i
    • Installs additional dependencies required for HANA runtime

Now, your project is ready to connect and deploy models to an HDI container.

 

13. Update package.json for HANA Deployment

 Open package.json → under "cds.requires" add:

"db": {
  "kind": "hana"
}

This tells CAP to use SAP HANA as the primary database in production.

 

14. Bind the CAP Project to Your HANA Instance

In BAS → Cloud Foundry view:

  1. Select your CAP app
  2. Choose Bind to Service
  3. Pick your HANA DB instance hanaDB

This automatically creates a .env file containing:

  • HDI container name
  • Credentials
  • Database URLs
  • Service keys

Why we are doing this

CAP needs this information to connect to SAP HANA for:

  • Local “cds watch”
  • Production deployment

Your project is now fully connected to SAP HANA Cloud.

 

15. Build Your CAP Project for Production

Run:

cds build –production

HANA Cloud can now deploy your database schema properly.

 

16. Deploy to SAP HANA Cloud

Run:

cds deploy --production

This:

  • Creates HDI container
  • Deploys CDS schema into HANA tables
  • Activates views, indexes, constraints

Your CAP application now uses SAP HANA Cloud as its primary DB.

 

17. Rebuild and Deploy the Entire CAP Application

Again perform:

mbt build

Then deploy:

cf deploy <yourfile>.mtar

 

Our complete application (service + database) is deployed on Cloud Foundry using HANA.

 

18. Verify Schema Deployment in SAP HANA Cloud

  1. Open SAP HANA Data Explorer
  2. Click +
  3. Select Instance Type = HDI
  4. Choose your CAP application HDI container    

 

        5. Expand Tables and Views

You can verify that:

  • Tables are created
  • Data model is deployed correctly

 

19. Running CAP Application Locally Using HANA Cloud

If you want to run locally via HANA:

  1. Ensure .env exists
  2. Rebind HDI container if needed

 

 

  1. Run:     
cds w

Successful connection check

If logs show:

Connected to SAP HANA Cloud (hanaDB) . Then your HDI container is successfully connected.

 

20. Validate Deployment Using Postman

 

This confirms:

  • Service is running
  • HANA DB is connected
  • Deployment is successful end-to-end

Conclusion

In this blog, we have completed the following activities:

  • Created a new CAP application using the BAS template wizard.

  • Performed an initial deployment using SQLite to verify application behavior.

  • Provisioned a SAP HANA Cloud instance and assigned all required role collections.

  • Enabled HANA support in the CAP project and generated HDI-related artifacts.

  • Bound the project to the HANA instance to establish secure database connectivity.

  • Built CDS artifacts for production and deployed them into the HDI container.

  • Rebuilt and deployed the full MTA application to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry using HANA as the primary database.

  • Verified successful deployment through SAP HANA Database Explorer and API testing.

entry.title: Automating a Simple SAP Lab Environment with Terraform and Ansible
entry.content:
This walkthrough demonstrates how to provision a lightweight SLES instance using Terraform, then automatically configure it using Ansible. The result is a clean, automated pipeline that can build and prepare a small SAP-style lab environment in minutes.

All identifying information (AWS account details, VPC IDs, Subnets, AMI IDs, SSH key names, IP addresses, etc.) is represented using placeholders.

Overview

This setup uses two main components:

1. Terraform (Infrastructure)

  • A SLES EC2 instance
  • A minimal security group
  • An SSH key pair reference
  • An Ansible-ready inventory line (via Terraform outputs)

2. Ansible (Configuration)

  • Basic packages
  • chronyd for time synchronisation
  • Simple SAP-friendly sysctl tuning

No SAP software is installed here. This is a lightweight foundation for further SAP experimentation.

Directory Structure

sap-lab/
├── run.sh
├── run_destroy.sh
│
├── terraform/
│   ├── main.tf
│   ├── <SSH_PUBLIC_KEY_FILENAME>.pub
│   └── terraform.tfstate   (generated automatically)
│
└── ansible/
    ├── inventory.ini
    ├── site.yml
    └── ansible.cfg

Terraform: main.tf

The following main.tf provisions a SLES instance and generates an Ansible inventory line.

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = "<AWS_REGION>"   # e.g. us-east-2
}

resource "aws_key_pair" "ssh_key" {
  key_name   = "<KEY_NAME>"                       # e.g. sap-lab-key
  public_key = file("${path.module}/<SSH_PUBLIC_KEY_FILENAME>.pub")
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_host_sg" {
  name        = "sap-host-sg"
  description = "Security group for SAP lab host"
  vpc_id      = "<VPC_ID>"

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]   # adjust for production
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  tags = {
    Name = "sap-host-sg"
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_host" {
  ami           = "<SLES_AMI_ID>"                # generic placeholder
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
  key_name      = aws_key_pair.ssh_key.key_name

  subnet_id                   = "<SUBNET_ID>"
  associate_public_ip_address = true

  vpc_security_group_ids = [
    aws_security_group.sap_host_sg.id
  ]

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-LAB-Host"
  }
}

output "ansible_inventory_line" {
  description = "Ansible inventory line for this host"
  value = "sap_host ansible_host=<EC2_PUBLIC_IP> ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=<PATH_TO_PRIVATE_KEY>/<SSH_PRIVATE_KEY_FILENAME>.pem ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'"
}

Ansible: site.yml

---
- name: Prepare host for SAP-style workloads
  hosts: sap_hosts
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Install basic packages
      ansible.builtin.zypper:
        name:
          - wget
          - net-tools
          - chrony
        state: present

    - name: Ensure chronyd is enabled and running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: chronyd
        state: started
        enabled: yes

    - name: Set SAP-friendly sysctl values
      ansible.posix.sysctl:
        name: vm.swappiness
        value: "10"
        state: present
        reload: yes

Ansible: inventory.ini

[sap_hosts]
sap_host ansible_host=<EC2_PUBLIC_IP> ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=<PATH_TO_PRIVATE_KEY>/<SSH_PRIVATE_KEY_FILENAME>.pem ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'

Automation script: run.sh

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

echo "=== Terraform apply ==="
cd terraform
terraform init -input=false
terraform apply -auto-approve -input=false

echo "=== Extracting host info for Ansible ==="
INVENTORY_LINE=$(terraform output -raw ansible_inventory_line)

cd ../ansible

echo "=== Writing inventory.ini ==="
{
  echo "[sap_hosts]"
  echo "$INVENTORY_LINE"
} > inventory.ini

echo "=== Running Ansible playbook ==="
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml

Automation script: run_destroy.sh

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

echo "=== Terraform destroy ==="
cd terraform
terraform destroy -auto-approve -input=false
cd ..

echo "=== Clearing Ansible inventory ==="
echo "# Inventory cleared after destroy" > ansible/inventory.ini

Running the lab

Build the environment

./run.sh

Destroy the environment

./run_destroy.sh

Conclusion

This tutorial provides a simple, repeatable way to spin up SAP-friendly Linux hosts on AWS: Terraform handles the infrastructure, and Ansible handles configuration. From here, you can extend the playbook with SAP Host Agent installation, Cloud Connector setup, or full SAP system preparation, while keeping the core workflow automated and reproducible.

Prove your skills and earn a certification that validates your expertise.

entry.title: Fast & Curious: The Making of an SAP Champion
entry.content:
On a Saturday morning in Hyderabad, Ruthvik Chowdary might be cruising towards a new destination with his playlist ready or volunteering at an SAP Inside Track event. Whether navigating winding roads or meeting fellow tech enthusiasts, Ruthvik thrives on exploring places, ideas, and opportunities.

That same spirit of discovery led him to SAP technology.

Inspired by his uncle, an experienced SAP Solution Architect, Ruthvik’s curiosity sparked during college. “He would discuss the problems he solved and SAP’s impact on businesses. It made him want to dive in.” And with his growing interest in manufacturing, it became the perfect starting point.

Guided by mentors and managers, Ruthvik soon broadened his expertise across the entire supply chain. He earned SAP Certifications spanning SAP Quality Management to SAP Extended Warehouse Management and now, as a Supply Chain Manager at Deloitte, confidently designs and optimizes end-to-end processes.

His breakthrough came during a training with a simulated supply bottleneck where he applied his knowledge to solve it. “That was when everything clicked. I understood not just the ‘how,’ but the ‘why.’ It was empowering.”

The path, however, was not without challenges. Ruthvik wrestled with complex configurations and moments of self-doubt early in his journey. “I wondered if I was really suited for SAP products.” Encouragement from his mentor, manager, and uncle reminded him that every expert starts as a beginner.

What continues to amaze him is SAP’s vastness and the constant innovation in cloud technologies. “It’s like an ocean. There’s always something new to learn.” Along the way, he developed unexpected strengths in communication and client engagement, becoming a trusted problem solver and mentor to others.

One of his proudest moments was being recognized as an SAP Champion for his contributions to the community. “Knowing my blogs helped others, even in interviews, is incredibly rewarding.”

From shadow consultant to SAP Champion, Ruthvik’s story is one of persistence, passion, and purpose. His advice to new learners is simple: “Dive in, stay curious, and do not be afraid to ask for help. The rewards are worth it.”

Ready to begin your own adventure? Explore structured learning journeys and certifications on the SAP Learning site and discover where curiosity can take you.

This can happen if you are creating the job requisition from position org chart where the operator role has not been populated via the rule.

KBA explains the behavior

entry.title: Re: ALV TREE: Select ALL - Deselect ALL
entry.content:
Ok, As Sandra said in the other thread the key is play with the item layout.

I've created two custom buttons to mark and unmark all the nodes. 
In my internal table GT_PEDIDOS I have the node key in the field NODO.
This is my solution:

FORM mark_all .

  DATA:
    ls_item_layout   TYPE lvc_s_laci.

  PERFORM item_layout USING abap_true CHANGING ls_item_layout.

  LOOP AT gt_pedidos ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_pedidos>)
    WHERE nodo IS NOT INITIAL.

    CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->change_item
      EXPORTING
        i_node_key     = <ls_pedidos>-nodo
        i_fieldname    = c_campo_seleccion
        i_data         = abap_false
*       i_u_data       = abap_true
        is_item_layout = ls_item_layout
      EXCEPTIONS
        node_not_found = 1
        OTHERS         = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*     Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->frontend_update.

ENDFORM.

FORM unmark_all.

  DATA:
    ls_item_layout   TYPE lvc_s_laci,
    lt_selected_node TYPE lvc_t_chit.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->get_checked_items
    IMPORTING
      et_checked_items = lt_selected_node.

  PERFORM item_layout USING abap_false CHANGING ls_item_layout.

  LOOP AT lt_selected_node ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_node>).

    CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->change_item
      EXPORTING
        i_node_key     = <ls_node>-nodekey
        i_fieldname    = 'MARK'
        i_data         = abap_false
*       i_u_data       = abap_true
        is_item_layout = ls_item_layout
      EXCEPTIONS
        node_not_found = 1
        OTHERS         = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*     Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.

  CALL METHOD go_alv_tree->frontend_update.

ENDFORM.

FORM item_layout USING p_lv_mark
                 CHANGING p_ls_layout TYPE lvc_s_laci.

  p_ls_layout-fieldname  = c_campo_seleccion.
  p_ls_layout-class      = cl_gui_column_tree=>item_class_checkbox.
  p_ls_layout-u_class    = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-editable   = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-u_editable = abap_true.
  p_ls_layout-u_chosen   = abap_true.

  p_ls_layout-chosen     = p_lv_mark.

ENDFORM.

entry.title: Material availability check in maintenance orders – SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello community,

We are working in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and have a question regarding material availability in maintenance orders.

In our scenario:

  • The required materials are stored in the warehouse.

  • When creating a maintenance order, we would like the system to indicate directly within the order whether the materials are available or not.

  • Additionally, if materials are not available, we would like the order status to be updated automatically to “Material shortage”.

So far, we have not found how to configure this availability check inside the maintenance order in the Public Cloud environment.

Is there a standard functionality in S/4HANA Public Cloud that shows material availability directly in the maintenance order and updates the status accordingly?

Or would this require additional configuration or process adjustments (e.g., reservations management, order customizing)?

Thank you very much for your support!

entry.title: Re: Hire Template Configuration: Supported MDF Object Types and Implementation Guidelines for Onboar
entry.content:
Hello @B-Ajaikaran ,

After completing Manage Pending Hires or on Day 1, if a custom MDF object already exists on the People Profile and the same object is included in the Onboarding template, the data will appear on the People Profile without any changes.

Likewise, when you add a non-effective dated entity to the Configurable New Hire Template, the object syncs to Employee Central automatically based on the existing People Profile configuration, with no extra setup required.

Regards,

Akarsh

entry.title: Re: Change Custom Font Family using UI Theme Designer
entry.content:
See SAP KBA 2812695 - How to Change the Default Font in UI Theme Designer

Resolution

  1. Upgrade UI Theme Designer to the latest version as per Note 2119552 - UI Theme Designer Upgrade Guide
  2. Then you can modify the "sapFontFamily" parameter as the font that you desired in UI Theme Designer.

Note: Customizing the Font size and Style is not possible from UI Theme Designer. You can do it via custom CSS, but please be aware that SAP is not responsible for issues caused by it and is not upgrade safe.

entry.title: Re: Why is the "create button" not displayed in CDSView?
entry.content:
Dear @AkiraMatsuda,

Why the Create / Copy / Delete buttons are missing, in Public Cloud:

  • Key user extensibility apps (including Custom CDS Views F1866A) are read-only in the productive system
  • You can only create or change Custom CDS Views in the Extensibility system:
    • 2-system landscape → Test/Quality system
    • 3-system landscape → Development / Customizing tenant

SAP Notes and SAP Community explicitly describe exactly your symptom: “Create/Edit/Delete buttons are disabled or missing” in Custom CDS Views in the productive tenant.

More details below from SAP Note and SAP Community:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2553539

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/custom-cds-views-faq/ba-p/13546765

Please confirm that the buttons are missing in the Production environment.

What you should do:

  1. Check which tenant you are logged into:
    • In Fiori Launchpad: user icon (top right) → About → check System ID / Tenant type
    • Make sure you are in the Extensibility Development / Quality system, not Production
  2. Log on to the correct system:
    • Use your Quality/Test (2-system) or Development/Customizing (3-system) tenant.
    • Open Custom CDS Views F1866A. The Create / Copy / Delete buttons should appear.
  3. (If this is a Starter or Demo system)
    • Extensibility may be turned off. Use the Extensibility Settings app to activate Key User Extensibility for the tenant.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3342103

       4. Transport to Production

Summary: You can’t enable the Create button in your productive tenant. You must create and maintain Custom CDS Views in the designated extensibility (Dev/QA) tenant and then transport them.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Congratulations, SAP Readiness Check!
entry.content:
As we get ready to celebrate the 100,000th SAP Readiness Check analysis processed, we would like to pause with a brief look at our milestone moments.

Following the release of SAP S/4HANA 1609, customers understood that SAP S/4HANA is different from SAP ECC and started asking questions about the impact of making the move and whether their systems were ready to undergo the transition. These inquiries led to the introduction of the SAP Readiness Check in 2017 as a manual service session to prepare service deliveries for MaxAttention customers looking to convert to SAP S/4HANA.

The first, semi-automated version of SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA went live in May 2019. Since then, SAP Readiness Check has continued to evolve, not only extending the depth of the checks but on top making SAP Readiness Check available for transitions beyond the conversion to SAP S/4HANA, expanding the coverage of SAP products and solutions to SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Supply Chain solutions, SAP Customer Experience solutions, SAP BW/4HANA, and SAP Cloud ALM. As of today, SAP Readiness Check is available on SAP for Me and SAP Cloud ALM, offering nine variants to support various transformation scenarios and has supported over 15,500 customers across 150 countries/regions.

And there’s more on the roadmap: In the future, we are planning to use genAI features in SAP Readiness Check that will guide users during setup, interpretation, and follow-up tasks. Furthermore, new SAP Readiness Check scenarios for RISE with SAP and SAP Business Suite customers are in the pipeline, evolving SAP Readiness Check to a continual source of information for customers, partners, and SAP teams to discuss where and how further SAP Business Suite products and offerings could optimize and enhance the customer’s active business processes. Stay tuned for more to come that supports the transition to new SAP solutions!

“SAP Readiness Check is a cornerstone of every successful SAP S/HANA transformation we support”, states Markus Schuetz, Senior Lead Architect at the SAP Partner Claranet Addon GmbH and workstream lead of the DSAG (German SAP User Group).

A big thank you to all customers and partners trusting in SAP Readiness Check as the basis for planning and preparing the transition to new strategic SAP solutions and into the cloud, and congratulations to all SAP colleagues contributing to the continuous success of SAP Readiness Check!

We invite you to comment on this blog to share your congrats, thoughts, and SAP Readiness Check success stories with the SAP Readiness Check Community!

Your SAP Readiness Check team
